explanation:
charsequalcaseless — need its prototype/definition to see what parameter types it accepts and whether it takes/returns pointers (affects whether any pointers passed to it from this function must be non-const). If it took pointer arguments or performed casts, that could force non-const qualification here.

isasciiupper — charsequalcaseless calls this; its definition/behaviour can show whether character classification relies on macros or functions that might use non-const pointer access or casts (relevant to transitive const-qualification concerns).

memcpy — prototype is required to confirm which parameter is treated as source (const) and which as destination (non-const). This determines whether cur_token or s2/buf could be const-qualified.

memchr — prototype shows it accepts a const void * first argument; confirms that passing token (const char *const) is compatible and does not force removal of const.

mhd_assert — macro/function definition is needed to ensure it does not perform any casts or take non-const pointer parameters that would require changing pointer qualifiers in this function.

ssize_t — the type of buf_size must be known to judge whether the pointer ssize_t *buf_size could or should be const-qualified (the function writes through it so likely cannot be const); the exact typedef matters for MISRA reasoning.

size_t — size parameter type used throughout; needed to verify interactions and casts between size_t and ssize_t that may affect whether pointers should be const.

SSIZE_MAX — its definition/value is used in the overflow check; understanding its type and use is relevant when reasoning about buf_size and whether changing qualifiers would break checks.

NULL — its definition (macro/constant) is required when reasoning about comparisons to NULL in asserts and ensuring no implicit casts force qualifier changes.

(Only these external symbols are required to determine whether any pointer in the target function could be made const or must remain non-const due to API/ABI requirements.)
